title: Halle Berry shows off sculpted figure in skintight workout gear as she emerges from NYC gym session
text:
She has retained a stunning movie star figure.

And Halle Berry showed off her trim frame in skintight workout gear when she was glimpsed leaving the gym in New York on Thursday.

The 53-year-old made sure to keep hydrated, carrying a water bottle and a bulging gym bag as she chatted on the sidewalk with a male pal.

On the move: Halle Berry showed off her trim frame in skintight workout gear when she was glimpsed leaving the gym in New York on Thursday

Halle is a longtime client of Los Angeles-based trainer Peter Lee Thomas, who praised her workout discipline to E! News last year.

'We typically meet up every day, 5 days a week. She's putting in the work. She doesn't mess around,' shared Peter.

'That's really, really great for me because I know that when we go there it's like preparing for war. There's an objective and there's a goal.'

The Catwoman actress was in Atlanta over the weekend for the star-studded grand opening gala of Tyler Perry Studios.

Legging it: The 53-year-old made sure to keep hydrated, carrying a water bottle and a bulging gym bag as she chatted on the sidewalk with a male pal

She went Chaplin chic in a black House Of Holland suit and matching bowler hat, posing alongside fellow Oscar-winner Whoopi Goldberg.

In a 2009 interview with the Telegraph, Whoopi memorably joked: 'OK, I don't look like Halle Berry. I'm 53 for God's sake. But one day she sure as hell will look like me.'

Tyler bought the Fort McPherson military base, which spreads across 330 acres, in 2015 and has now made it the site of his massive studio.

The $250 million property is the first studio owned by a black American - on ground once occupied by a Confederate base.

Jet set: The Catwoman actress was in Atlanta over the weekend for the star-studded grand opening gala of Tyler Perry Studios

Tyler remarked on the historical detail while accepting the ultimate icon award at the BET Awards over the summer.

'That studio was once a Confederate Army base - and I want you to hear this - which meant that there was Confederate soldiers on that base plotting and planning on how to keep 3.9 million Negroes enslaved,' he said.

'Now, that land is owned by one Negro,' he said to a standing ovation, then added: 'It's all about trying to help somebody across.'

He shared: 'While everybody was fighting for a seat at the table, talking about: "Oscars so white, Oscars so white," I said: "Y'all go ahead and do that, but while you're fighting for a seat at the table, I'll be down in Atlanta building my own."'
